message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Experimental study of inequality and unpredictability in an artificial cultural market
Paper Abstract: Hit songs, books, and movies are many times more successful than average, suggesting that "the best" alternatives are qualitatively different from "the rest"; yet experts routinely fail to predict which products will succeed. We investigated this paradox experimentally, by creating an artificial "music market" in which 14,341 participants downloaded previously unknown songs either with or without knowledge of previous participants' choices. Increasing the strength of social influence increased both inequality and unpredictability of success. Success was also only partly determined by quality: The best songs rarely did poorly, and the worst rarely did well, but any other result was possible.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Predictability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictability"},{"title":"Predictable process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictable_process"},{"title":"Randomness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomness"},{"title":"Coefficient of multiple correlation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coefficient_of_multiple_correlation"},{"title":"Potential predictability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_predictability"},{"title":"Predictive validity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_validity"},{"title":"Predictive analytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_analytics"},{"title":"Decomposition of time series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition_of_time_series"},{"title":"Prediction interval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prediction_interval"},{"title":"Google Trends - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Trends"}]

Here are the search results for "Predictability statistics":

## Key Concepts

**General Predictability**: Predictability is the degree to which a correct prediction or forecast of a system's state can be made, either qualitatively or quantitatively.

**Statistical Measures**: In statistics, several metrics are used to quantify predictability:

- **Coefficient of Multiple Correlation**: The coefficient of multiple correlation is a measure of how well a given variable can be predicted using a linear function of a set of other variables.(no content)The coefficient of multiple correlation takes values between 0 and 1, with higher values indicating higher predictability of the dependent variable from the independent variables, where a value of 1 indicates that predictions are exactly correct.

- **Prediction Intervals**: A prediction interval is an estimate of an interval in which a future observation will fall, with a certain probability, given what has already been observed.

- **Potential Predictability**: The term potential predictability is used in weather forecasting to describe the extent that the future weather can be predicted in principle, describing the proportion of variance in the weather that arises from systematic factors rather than random noise.

## Applications

**Predictive Analytics**: The core of predictive analytics relies on capturing relationships between explanatory variables and the predicted variables from past occurrences, and exploiting them to predict the unknown outcome.

**Psychometrics**: In psychometrics, predictive validity is the extent to which a score on a scale or test predicts scores on some criterion measure.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- **Coefficient of Multiple Correlation**: The coefficient of multiple correlation is a measure of how well a given variable can be predicted using a linear function of a set of other variables.(no content)The coefficient of multiple correlation takes values between 0 and 1, with higher values indicating higher predictability of the dependent variable from the independent variables, where a value of 1 indicates that predictions are exactly correct.

- **Prediction Intervals**: A prediction interval is an estimate of an interval in which a future observation will fall, with a certain probability, given what has already been observed.

- **Potential Predictability**: The term potential predictability is used in weather forecasting to describe the extent that the future weather can be predicted in principle, describing the proportion of variance in the weather that arises from systematic factors rather than random noise.

## Applications

**Predictive Analytics**: The core of predictive analytics relies on capturing relationships between explanatory variables and the predicted variables from past occurrences, and exploiting them to predict the unknown outcome.

**Psychometrics**: In psychometrics, predictive validity is the extent to which a score on a scale or test predicts scores on some criterion measure.

I've completed the web search for "Product quality assessment." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Product Quality Assessment

Quality management ensures that an organization, product, or service consistently performs as intended, with four main components: quality planning, quality assurance, quality control, and quality improvement.

## Key Approaches and Methods

**Quality Assurance (QA):** Quality assurance is the term used in both manufacturing and service industries to describe the systematic efforts taken to assure that the product(s) delivered to customer(s) meet with the contractual and other agreed upon performance, design, reliability, and maintainability expectations of that customer.

**Quality Control (QC):** Quality control is a process by which entities review the quality of all factors involved in production, defined by ISO 9000 as "a part of quality management focused on fulfilling quality requirements".

**Product Testing:** Product testing is any process by means of which a researcher measures a product's performance, safety, quality, and compliance with established standards.

## Quality Dimensions

Garvin's eight dimensions of quality include: Performance (brands can be ranked objectively on product performance aspects), Features (additional characteristics that enhance appeal), Reliability (the product works without fail for adequate time), and Conformance (the product is made exactly as the designer intended).

These search results provide comprehensive information on how product quality is defined, assessed, and managed across various industries.

Web search results for query: "Social influence"

Links: [{"title":"Social influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence"},{"title":"Normative social influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normative_social_influence"},{"title":"Social influence bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence_bias"},{"title":"Social proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_proof"},{"title":"Social influences on fitness behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influences_on_fitness_behavior"},{"title":"Interpersonal influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_influence"},{"title":"Social contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contagion"},{"title":"Social marketing intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_marketing_intelligence"},{"title":"Influence of mass media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influence_of_mass_media"},{"title":"Media and teen relationships - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_and_teen_relationships"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social influence:

## Overview

Social influence is a broad term that relates to many different phenomena. It encompasses the ways that individuals and groups are affected by the behavior and expectations of others.

## Key Types of Social Influence

### Informational and Normative Influence

Two psychological needs lead humans to conform to the expectations of others: the need to be right (informational social influence) and the need to be liked (normative social influence).(no content)Informational influence (or social proof) is an influence to accept information from another as evidence about reality, and comes into play when people are uncertain, either from stimuli being intrinsically ambiguous or because of social disagreement.(no content)Normative social influence involves a change in behavior that is deemed necessary in order to fit in a particular group.

### Conformity

Conformity is a type of social influence involving a change in behavior, belief, or thinking to align with those of others or with normative standards, and is the most common and pervasive form of social influence.

### Social Contagion

Social contagion involves the spontaneous spread of behaviors or emotions through a group, population or social network, and consists of two categories: behavioral contagion and emotional contagion.

## Mechanisms and Effects

Compliance is the act of responding favorably to an explicit or implicit request offered by others. Compliance is a behavior change but not necessarily in attitude; one can comply due to mere obedience or by otherwise opting to withhold private thoughts due to social pressures.(no content)Normative social influence can be a very powerful, yet unconscious, motivator of behavior.

Web search results for query: "Inequality economics"

Links: [{"title":"Economic inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality"},{"title":"Economic inequality in China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality_in_China"},{"title":"History of economic inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_economic_inequality"},{"title":"Tax policy and economic inequality in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_policy_and_economic_inequality_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Effects of economic inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effects_of_economic_inequality"},{"title":"Economic inequality in South Korea - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality_in_South_Korea"},{"title":"Economic inequality in New Zealand - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality_in_New_Zealand"},{"title":"The Journal of Economic Inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Journal_of_Economic_Inequality"},{"title":"Income inequality in India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_inequality_in_India"},{"title":"Spatial inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_inequality"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of inequality economics:

## Definition and Components

Economic inequality is an umbrella term for three concepts: income inequality, how the total sum of money paid to people is distributed among them; wealth inequality, how the total sum of wealth owned by people is distributed among the owners; and consumption inequality, how the total sum of money spent by people is distributed among the spenders.

## Measurement

The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion intended to represent the income inequality, wealth inequality, or consumption inequality within a nation or a social group.

## Global Trends

Whereas globalization has reduced the inequality between nations, it has increased the inequality within most nations, particularly among advanced countries in the last 30 years.(no content)The 2024 Oxfam report found a significant increase in inequality as roughly five billion people have become poorer while at the same time the fortunes of the five richest individuals have doubled, with current trends paving the way for the world's first trillionaire within a decade.

## Economic and Social Effects

Research suggests that greater inequality hinders economic growth and macroeconomic stability, and that inequality of land and human capital reduce growth more than inequality of income.(no content)Effects of income inequality include higher rates of health and social problems, and lower rates of social goods, a lower population-wide satisfaction and happiness and even a lower level of economic growth when human capital is neglected for high-end consumption.(no content)Research has generally linked economic inequality to political and social instability, including revolution, democratic breakdown and civil conflict.

## Policy Response

In advanced economies, taxes and transfers decrease income inequality by one-third, with most of this being achieved via public social spending (such as pensions and family benefits).

The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion intended to represent the income inequality, wealth inequality, or consumption inequality within a nation or a social group.

## Global Trends

Whereas globalization has reduced the inequality between nations, it has increased the inequality within most nations, particularly among advanced countries in the last 30 years.(no content)The 2024 Oxfam report found a significant increase in inequality as roughly five billion people have become poorer while at the same time the fortunes of the five richest individuals have doubled, with current trends paving the way for the world's first trillionaire within a decade.

## Economic and Social Effects

Research suggests that greater inequality hinders economic growth and macroeconomic stability, and that inequality of land and human capital reduce growth more than inequality of income.(no content)Effects of income inequality include higher rates of health and social problems, and lower rates of social goods, a lower population-wide satisfaction and happiness and even a lower level of economic growth when human capital is neglected for high-end consumption.(no content)Research has generally linked economic inequality to political and social instability, including revolution, democratic breakdown and civil conflict.

## Policy Response

In advanced economies, taxes and transfers decrease income inequality by one-third, with most of this being achieved via public social spending (such as pensions and family benefits).

Links: [{"title":"Bounded rationality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality"},{"title":"Rational choice model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_choice_model"},{"title":"Herbert A. Simon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon"},{"title":"Behavioral economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_economics"},{"title":"Bounded rationality in environmental decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_rationality_in_environmental_decision_making"},{"title":"Satisficing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisficing"},{"title":"A Behavioral Theory of the Firm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Behavioral_Theory_of_the_Firm"},{"title":"Consumption (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumption_(economics)"},{"title":"Behavioral law and economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_law_and_economics"},{"title":"Rationalization (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rationalization_(economics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about bounded rationality in economic behavior:

## Overview

Bounded rationality is the idea that when individuals make decisions, their rationality is limited by the tractability of the decision problem, their cognitive limitations and the time available.(no content)Bounded rationality addresses the discrepancy between the assumed perfect rationality of human behaviour (which is utilized by other economics theories), and the reality of human cognition.

## Key Concept

Bounded rationality revises notions of perfect rationality to account for the fact that perfectly rational decisions are often not feasible in practice because of the intractability of natural decision problems and the finite computational resources available for making them.

## Origin and Development

Herbert A. Simon proposed bounded rationality as an alternative basis for the mathematical modeling of decision-making.(no content)Simon believed that factors like uncertainty about the future and costs in acquiring information limit the extent to which agents may make a fully rational decision, thus they possess only "bounded rationality" and must make decisions by "satisficing", or choosing that which might not be optimal, but which will make them happy enough.

## Practical Implications

Bounded rationality finds that actors do not assess all available options appropriately, in order to save on search and deliberation costs. Instead agents choose to settle for an acceptable solution.(no content)Economic agents use heuristics to make decisions rather than a strict rigid rule of optimization because of the complexity of the situation.

## Modern Applications

In economic models based on behavioral economics, agents often follow a sequence of simple rule-of-thumb behavior instead of an optimization procedure. This concept has become central to behavioral economics and continues to influence policy decisions and organizational strategy.

Web search results for query: "Market experiment economics"

Links: [{"title":"Experimental economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_economics"},{"title":"Vernon L. Smith - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vernon_L._Smith"},{"title":"Edward Chamberlin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Chamberlin"},{"title":"Experimental finance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_finance"},{"title":"Marketing experimentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marketing_experimentation"},{"title":"Talk:Experimental economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Experimental_economics"},{"title":"Behavioral economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_economics"},{"title":"Efficient-market hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efficient-market_hypothesis"},{"title":"Natural experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_experiment"},{"title":"Market (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_(economics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of market experiments in economics:

## Definition and Purpose

Experimental economics is the application of experimental methods to study economic questions.(no content)Data collected in experiments are used to estimate effect size, test the validity of economic theories, and illuminate market mechanisms.(no content)Experiments are used to help understand how and why markets and other exchange systems function as they do.

## Methodology

Economic experiments usually use cash to motivate subjects, in order to mimic real-world incentives.(no content)Experiments may be conducted in the field or in laboratory settings, whether of individual or group behavior.

## Historical Development

Edward Chamberlin is thought to have conducted "not only the first market experiment, but also the first economic experiment of any kind."(no content)Vernon L. Smith began his work in experimental economics at Purdue University, where he resolved to run a market experiment that would give students an opportunity to experience an actual market.(no content)Smith found that in some forms of centralized trading, prices and quantities traded in such markets converge on the values that would be predicted by the economic theory of perfect competition, despite the conditions not meeting many of the assumptions of perfect competition.(no content)In 2002, Smith was awarded (jointly with Daniel Kahneman) the Bank of Sweden Prize in Economic Sciences "for having established laboratory experiments as a tool in empirical economic analysis, especially in the study of alternative market mechanisms".

## Applications

Market experiments have been applied to various fields, including corporate finance, asset pricing, financial econometrics, international finance, personal financial decision-making, macro-finance, banking and financial intermediation, capital markets, risk management and insurance, derivatives, quantitative finance, corporate governance and compensation, investments, and market mechanisms.
